summary: This is an FBI Crisis Intake report documenting a social media tip received via Twitter on September 14, 2019, concerning a potential threat to life related to the Jeffrey Epstein child sex trafficking case. The report details the automated monitoring and triage process for social media threats.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named in the case title as the subject of a child sex trafficking investigation.

persons.name: Caligirz4trump
persons.context: Twitter user who posted a message expressing concern that a girl might end up dead and urging the FBI and DOJ to follow and share her story, linking to the Epstein case.

events.title: Social Media Tip Posted
events.description: Twitter user 'Caligirz4trump' posts a message expressing concern for a girl's safety in relation to the Epstein case, using the hashtag #KAG2020 and tagging the FBI and DOJ.

events.title: FBI Crisis Intake Report Generated
events.description: The FBI's National Threat Operations Center generates a crisis intake report (Case ID 31E-NY-3027571) after automated monitoring flags the social media post containing the keyword 'Dead'.

keyFacts: The document reveals the FBI's automated system for monitoring social media for threats related to high-profile cases like Epstein's.
A public tip expressed fear that a girl connected to the Epstein case might be killed, indicating ongoing public concern about witness safety.
The tip was triaged through the FBI's National Threat Operations Center, though the initial assessment found 'Threat To Life: False'.
The case ID (31E-NY-3027571) links this social media tip directly to the Epstein child sex trafficking investigation.
